japan_survey.description: Best practices for CRS selection in surveying and mapping within Japan

practices.title: Use JGD2011 (EPSG:6668) as the standard
practices.description: Use JGD2011 based on the Survey Act for surveying and mapping within Japan
practices.rationale: Official geodetic datum of Japan with consistency with GSI products
practices.example: Creating base maps, cadastral maps, urban planning maps

practices.title: Select the appropriate Japan Plane Rectangular CS
practices.description: Select the appropriate Japan Plane Rectangular CS (Zone I-XIX) for the target area
practices.rationale: Different zones mean different coordinate values, leading to inaccurate calculations
practices.example: Tokyo → Zone IX (EPSG:6677), Sapporo, Hokkaido → Zone XII (EPSG:6680)

practices.title: Manage wide-area data in geographic CRS
practices.description: Store data spanning multiple zones in geographic CRS (EPSG:6668) and project as needed
practices.rationale: Prevents loss of continuity at zone boundaries

practices.title: Use appropriate decimal places based on coordinate precision
practices.description: Plane rectangular coordinates: millimeter precision (3 decimal places), Geographic coordinates: approximately 8 decimal places
practices.rationale: Excessive precision is meaningless, insufficient precision degrades data quality

commonMistakes.consequence: 1-2m coordinate difference from JGD2011 causes misalignment with other data
commonMistakes.solution: Convert to JGD2011 and record conversion history in metadata

commonMistakes.mistake: Treating data from different zones as the same zone
commonMistakes.consequence: Coordinate values differ greatly, causing inaccurate calculations
commonMistakes.solution: Verify zone information of data and transform coordinates as needed

references.title: Standards for Public Survey Work Procedures

web_mapping.description: Best practices for CRS selection in web application map display and interaction

practices.title: Use Web Mercator (EPSG:3857) for web map display
practices.description: Standard tile coordinate system for Leaflet, MapLibre, Google Maps, etc.
practices.rationale: Major web map libraries and tile services adopt this coordinate system

practices.title: Output GeoJSON in WGS84 (EPSG:4326)
practices.description: WGS84 is the standard in the GeoJSON specification
practices.rationale: Ensures interoperability through specification compliance

practices.title: Do not perform area/distance calculations in Web Mercator
practices.description: When accurate area/distance calculations are needed, convert to geographic CRS or appropriate projected CRS
practices.rationale: Web Mercator has significant area distortion at high latitudes (4x at 60° latitude)

practices.title: Use appropriate projected CRS for high-precision functions
practices.description: Convert to purpose-appropriate coordinate system for distance measurement, area calculation, buffer generation, etc.
practices.rationale: Minimize errors from projection distortion

commonMistakes.consequence: Approximately 23% area distortion even in Japan (around 35° latitude)
commonMistakes.solution: Convert to JGD2011 Plane Rectangular CS or equal-area projection before area calculation

commonMistakes.consequence: Cannot be read correctly by other GIS software
commonMistakes.solution: Output GeoJSON in WGS84 (EPSG:4326), omit CRS property

data_exchange.description: Best practices for CRS selection in data exchange between organizations and systems

practices.title: Include CRS information in data
practices.description: Include EPSG code in metadata and record transformation history
practices.rationale: Data with unknown CRS causes confusion during use

practices.title: Use WGS84 for international data exchange
practices.description: Use WGS84 (EPSG:4326) as the reference for data exchange across countries and regions
practices.rationale: Reference for GPS satellites and universally recognized worldwide

practices.title: Specify transformation accuracy
practices.description: When coordinate transformation is performed, record transformation method and accuracy in metadata
practices.rationale: Allows recipients to evaluate accuracy

commonMistakes.consequence: Recipients interpret incorrect coordinate system, causing position misalignment
commonMistakes.solution: Always include CRS information (EPSG code) in metadata

coordinate_storage.description: Best practices for storing coordinate data in databases and files

practices.title: Use geographic CRS for long-term storage
practices.description: Store in geographic CRS (EPSG:4326 or EPSG:6668) in databases
practices.rationale: Projected CRS may change in the future, but geographic CRS is stable

practices.title: Use numeric types appropriate for coordinate precision
practices.description: DOUBLE type for lat/lon, DECIMAL(12,3) or similar for projected coordinates
practices.rationale: FLOAT type may have insufficient precision

practices.title: Unify CRS for spatial indexes
practices.description: Use a unified CRS when creating spatial indexes in PostGIS, etc.
practices.rationale: Data in different CRS cannot be correctly compared in spatial queries

commonMistakes.consequence: Only about 7 digits of precision, potentially 10m or more error in lat/lon
commonMistakes.solution: Use DOUBLE type or DECIMAL type

mobile_gps.description: Best practices for using location information on smartphones and GPS devices

practices.title: Recognize that GPS output is WGS84
practices.description: GPS satellite systems use WGS84, and output coordinates are also WGS84
practices.rationale: Misidentifying the datum causes 1-2m or more displacement

practices.title: Understand GPS accuracy limitations
practices.description: Consumer GPS: several meters to 10m, DGPS: about 1m, RTK: several cm
practices.rationale: Discussions beyond accuracy are meaningless

practices.title: Convert to JGD2011 for storing data within Japan
practices.description: WGS84 and JGD2011 are practically identical, but conversion recommended for consistency in domestic data management
practices.rationale: Coordinate difference is within a few cm, but maintains metadata consistency

commonMistakes.mistake: Treating GPS data as Tokyo Datum
commonMistakes.consequence: Displacement of 400m or more from actual position
commonMistakes.solution: Recognize that GPS output is WGS84 and process appropriately

historical_data.description: Best practices for handling data created in the past

practices.title: Convert Tokyo Datum data before use
practices.description: Convert Tokyo Datum (EPSG:4301) data to JGD2011 before use
practices.rationale: Ensures consistency with current geodetic datum

practices.title: Recognize transformation accuracy limitations
practices.description: Tokyo Datum → JGD2011 transformation accuracy is limited to 1-2m
practices.rationale: Discussions beyond accuracy are meaningless; compare with precision requirements

practices.title: Preserve original datum information
practices.description: Retain original datum information and parameters as metadata even after conversion
practices.rationale: Needed for future verification or re-transformation

commonMistakes.mistake: Using old data without datum information as-is
commonMistakes.consequence: Large displacement when overlaying with new data
commonMistakes.solution: Investigate data origin, estimate appropriate datum, and transform

cross_border.description: Best practices for CRS selection in cross-border data and international projects

practices.title: Use WGS84 as the common reference
practices.description: Use WGS84 (EPSG:4326) as the reference coordinate system for international data exchange
practices.rationale: Universally recognized worldwide and reference for GPS satellites

practices.title: Utilize UTM coordinate system
practices.description: Use UTM zones when wide-area projected coordinates are needed
practices.rationale: Defined worldwide with high interoperability

commonMistakes.solution: Convert to common coordinate system (WGS84, etc.) before merging

gis_integration.description: Best practices for handling CRS in GIS software and system integration

practices.title: Clearly define project CRS
practices.description: Determine CRS at project start and document it
practices.rationale: Later changes cause significant rework

practices.title: Don't over-rely on on-the-fly transformation
practices.description: On-the-fly transformation for display is convenient, but explicitly transform before analysis/output
practices.rationale: On-the-fly transformation affects performance and can cause unexpected rounding errors

practices.title: Verify CRS when loading data
practices.description: Check CRS information before loading new data
practices.rationale: Prevents mixing of data with unknown or incorrect CRS

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting CRS for unknown data based on guesswork
commonMistakes.consequence: All spatial calculation results become inaccurate if actual CRS differs
commonMistakes.solution: Verify data source, contact provider if necessary

precision_requirements.description: Setting and achieving precision requirements according to use case

practices.title: Set precision according to use case
practices.description: Car navigation: several meters, Urban planning: tens of cm, Surveying: sub-cm
practices.rationale: Excessive precision increases cost, insufficient precision fails requirements

practices.title: Select coordinate system appropriate for precision
practices.description: Projected CRS for high precision needs, Geographic CRS for wide areas
practices.rationale: Match coordinate system characteristics with precision requirements

commonMistakes.mistake: Expecting millimeter precision from GPS data
commonMistakes.consequence: Discussion beyond measurement limits becomes meaningless precision debate
commonMistakes.solution: Understand the precision limits of data sources

projection_selection.description: How to select projection methods according to purpose

practices.title: Select projection method according to purpose
practices.description: Conformal projection (shape preservation), Equal-area projection (area preservation), Equidistant projection (distance preservation)
practices.rationale: Impossible to preserve all characteristics simultaneously

practices.title: Use Japan Plane Rectangular CS for surveying in Japan
practices.description: Transverse Mercator (conformal) enables high-precision distance and angle calculations
practices.rationale: Standard for public surveys and legally recognized

practices.title: Use Web Mercator for web maps
practices.description: Can represent the entire world on a single map and compatible with tile division
practices.rationale: De facto standard for web maps

commonMistakes.mistake: Creating statistical maps with Web Mercator
commonMistakes.consequence: High-latitude areas are exaggerated in area, causing misunderstanding
commonMistakes.solution: Use equal-area projection for statistical maps
